title: Unlocking tool
data:
| ( [![Skeleton key.png](/images/e/ec/Skeleton_key.png)](/wiki/File:Skeleton_key.png) |                                                                                 |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                                | skeleton key                                                                    |
| Appearance                                                                          | key                                                                             |
| Base price                                                                          | 10 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")                                                |
| Weight                                                                              | [3](/wiki/Weight "Weight")                                                      |
| Material                                                                            | [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron")                                                       |
| Monster use                                                                         | *May be used [offensively](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item") by monsters.* |

| ( [![Lock pick.png](/images/0/01/Lock_pick.png)](/wiki/File:Lock_pick.png) |                                                                                 |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                       | lock pick                                                                       |
| Appearance                                                                 | lock pick                                                                       |
| Base price                                                                 | 20 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")                                                |
| Weight                                                                     | [4](/wiki/Weight "Weight")                                                      |
| Material                                                                   | [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron")                                                       |
| Monster use                                                                | *May be used [offensively](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item") by monsters.* |

| ( [![Credit card.png](/images/5/52/Credit_card.png)](/wiki/File:Credit_card.png) |                                    |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                             | credit card                        |
| Appearance                                                                       | credit card                        |
| Base price                                                                       | 10 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")   |
| Weight                                                                           | [1](/wiki/Weight "Weight")         |
| Material                                                                         | [plastic](/wiki/Plastic "Plastic") |
| Monster use                                                                      | *Will not be used by monsters.*    |

There are three **unlocking tools** in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*: the **skeleton key**, the **lock pick** (**osaku** to [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai")) and the **credit card**. The skeleton key and the lock pick are the only items allowing you to lock *and* unlock [doors](/wiki/Door "Door") and [chests](/wiki/Chest "Chest"). Credit cards can only unlock doors and chests, as a reference to their popularity in films for jimmying open door locks.

*NetHack* has two [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") unlocking tools: [The Master Key of Thievery](/wiki/The_Master_Key_of_Thievery "The Master Key of Thievery") and [The Platinum Yendorian Express Card](/wiki/The_Platinum_Yendorian_Express_Card "The Platinum Yendorian Express Card").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Effects](#Effects)

  - [2.1 Usage](#Usage)
  - [2.2 Onlookers](#Onlookers)
  - [2.3 Monster use](#Monster_use)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)

    - [5.1.1 Breakage](#Breakage)
    - [5.1.2 Strategy](#Strategy_2)

  - [5.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)

- [6 See also](#See_also)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

All unlocking tools are generated uncursed unless found on a [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") level; since [3.6.1](/wiki/3.6.1 "3.6.1"), they can also be found among the cursed items in the "bones" generated on some [traps](/wiki/Trap "Trap").

## Effects

### Usage

To unlock doors, [apply](/wiki/Apply "Apply") the unlocking tool and then choose the direction of the door. To unlock chests, apply the unlocking tool while standing on the chest and then choose ">", for down or ".", for here.

The chance of successfully locking or unlocking a door depends on which tool you use, your [dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity"), the type of lock, and whether or not you are a [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue"). The per-turn probabilities of success are listed in the table below. A cursed unlocking tool will also have a halved chance of success, applied after all other modifiers.

| Tool                       | For Rogues     |                                            | For non-Rogues |           |
| -------------------------- | -------------- | ------------------------------------------ | -------------- | --------- |
|                            | Door           | Box                                        | Door           | Box       |
| skeleton key               | (70+Dex)%      | (75+Dex)%                                  | (70+Dex)%      | (75+Dex)% |
| lock pick                  | (3\*Dex + 30)% | (4\*Dex + 25)%                             | (3\*Dex)%      | (4\*Dex)% |
| credit card                | (2\*Dex + 20)% | (Dex + 20)%                                | (2\*Dex)%      | (Dex)%    |
| Any weapon (bladed or not) | (not possible) | 2\*wldam (die size against large monsters) | (not possible) | 2\*wldam  |

For Rogues, the lock pick has a higher (un)locking chance than the key for boxes at dexterity 17 or higher, and for doors at dexterity 21 or higher (usually achievable only with [gauntlets of dexterity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_dexterity "Gauntlets of dexterity")). For non-rogues, the key is better than the lock-pick except at normally unreachable dexterity levels, and in all cases the lock-pick has better chances than the credit card.

If you have not succeeded after 50 turns, you give up. This [exercises](/wiki/Exercise "Exercise") your [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") if using a non-bladed weapon, and exercises [dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") if using a tool or bladed weapon; the exercise is only counted once you've succeeded or given up. each failed attempt is worth nothing alone.

When unlocking chests and boxes with bladed weapons vs. other weapons, the chance of succeeding is the same, but the effects are different. Edged weapons have a small chance of breaking on every failed unlock attempt. Non-edged weapons have a 33% chance of damaging the chest, which destroys the lock completely; in that case, all potions within are broken, along with a 33% chance of breaking every other item.

The message given varies depending on the material involved, as detailed below, and occurs in the form "A(n) \<item> \<message>!" (e.g. "An orange potion shatters!")

| Material      | Message                |
| ------------- | ---------------------- |
| Paper         | torn to shreds         |
| Wax           | crushed                |
| Veggy         | pulped                 |
| Flesh         | mashed                 |
| Glass         | shatters               |
| Wood          | splinters to fragments |
| Anything else | destroyed              |

### Onlookers

If a [watchman](/wiki/Watchman "Watchman") sees you picking a lock, he may warn you or become [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile"). If a warning is given, a trap is automatically added to the door in question.

Attempting to apply a credit card at a shopkeeper or the Oracle will produce the message "No checks, no credit, no problem." Attempting to apply an unlocking tool on a visible monster (other than a disguised mimic) in any other situation will produce the message "I don't think *\<monster>* would appreciate that.".

### Monster use

Some monsters with unlocking tools in their inventories may use them to unlock doors. [\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

Credit cards are the lightest unlocking tool, but also the slowest, and cannot re-lock objects like the others. Lock picks are the heaviest and most expensive, and for a Rogue with 18 dexterity they give a 97% chance of (un)locking a box in one turn. However, in all other circumstances, skeleton keys are faster, as well as cheaper and lighter.

Being corroded or rusted does not impede the operation of any unlocking tool; however, [cursed](/wiki/BUC "BUC") tools have only half the chance of unlocking that uncursed tools have.

While it is possible and sometimes reasonable to kick down doors, especially when without an unlocking tool, it has some adverse consequences.

- Kicking wakes up nearby monsters. This includes the fabled invisible [nymph](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph"). (This can have a major effect on your game, and is one of the main reasons you might choose to avoid kicking doors.)
- You cannot close and/or lock doors to partition out spawned monsters if you have kicked them down (unless you have the [wizard lock](/wiki/Wizard_lock "Wizard lock") spell or a [wand of locking](/wiki/Wand_of_locking "Wand of locking")).
- For characters with low [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") and [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution"), kicking can take longer, unless wearing kicking boots. (Note that for characters with high values in those physical statistics, even an unlocked door can be faster to kick down than to open naturally if approached on the diagonal, because open doors, as opposed to destroyed doors, must be approached orthogonally.)
- The door might be attached to a shop [closed for inventory](/wiki/Closed_for_inventory "Closed for inventory"). (You can check this by examining the square orthogonally next to the door using the `:` command, except in a few corner cases related to [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") levels.)
- Kicking doors is impossible while [riding](/wiki/Riding "Riding") or [levitating](/wiki/Levitation "Levitation").

## History

All the unlocking tools first appear in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). In addition, the NetHack 3.0 Series had special shaped keys that fit specific locks on chests and [large boxes](/wiki/Large_box "Large box"). For example, you might see "a chest (triangular keyhole)", for example, and a "triangular key" would open its lock much more quickly than a skeleton key, but a "square key" would not fit.

Doors did not have locks of any specific shape, and the shaped keys could not open them; you had to use one of the other unlocking tools.

Keys, and the locks that they fit, were as follows in [NetHack 3.0.10](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.10 "NetHack 3.0.10"):

| Key          | Lock         |
| ------------ | ------------ |
| round        | round        |
| square       | square       |
| triangular   | triangular   |
| oval         | oval         |
| octagonal    | octagonal    |
| hexagonal    | hexagonal    |
| cylindrical  | wide         |
| irregular    | notched      |
| conical      | large round  |
| wedge-shaped | large square |

In time, the shaped keys were believed to add nothing of value to the game, and in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0") they were removed.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") changes unlocking tools, adding a chance of breaking[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3), and also adding some [artifact keys](/wiki/Alignment_key "Alignment key"). Blessed unlocking tools and artifact unlocking tools will never break.

#### Breakage

| Tool         | Breakage Chance                                            |
| ------------ | ---------------------------------------------------------- |
| credit card  | 1/20                                                       |
|              | 1/30 ([tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") picking a *door*) |
| skeleton key | 1/15                                                       |
| lockpick     | 1/30                                                       |
|              | 1/40 ([rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue"))                        |

#### Strategy

Since the unlocking tools now break, it is a good idea to carry more than one on your person. There's nothing worse than locking yourself into a [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop"), only to have your pick break when you try to get out again!

Once you get an artifact unlocking tool, this becomes less of a problem. Generally, you'll only need to worry about it [being](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph") *[stolen](/wiki/Pixie "Pixie")*. Note that the alignment keys are available to all players who progress far enough into the game. After this, use the key matching your alignment to avoid [artifact blast](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast"), and keep the other keys in your [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding") or in a [stash](/wiki/Stash "Stash").

### UnNetHack

Starting with version 5.1, it is possible for [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") monsters to pick up keys and use them to unlock doors.

## See also

- [wand of opening](/wiki/Wand_of_opening "Wand of opening")
- [wand of locking](/wiki/Wand_of_locking "Wand of locking")
- [spellbook of knock](/wiki/Spellbook_of_knock "Spellbook of knock")
- [spellbook of wizard lock](/wiki/Spellbook_of_wizard_lock "Spellbook of wizard lock")
- [The Master Key of Thievery](/wiki/The_Master_Key_of_Thievery "The Master Key of Thievery"), an artifact skeleton key
- [The Platinum Yendorian Express Card](/wiki/The_Platinum_Yendorian_Express_Card "The Platinum Yendorian Express Card"), an artifact credit card
- [Alignment key](/wiki/Alignment_key "Alignment key") (SLASH'EM only)

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [monmove.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 43](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.6.0/monmove.c#line43 "Source:NetHack 3.6.0/monmove.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [lock.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 416](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/lock.c#line416 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/lock.c") boxes, chests
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [lock.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 518](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/lock.c#line518 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/lock.c") doors

*This page is based on a spoiler by [Dylan O'Donnell](https://alt.org/nethack/mirror/www.spod-central.org/%257Epsmith/). The original license is:*

Redistribution, copying, and editing of these spoilers, with or without modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions are met:

1. The original contributors to any spoiler must continue to be credited.
2. Any modifications to the spoiler must be acknowledged and credited.

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.0. Click here for more information.](/images/d/d6/Nh360-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.0. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-360}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Unlocking tool

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
(
Name skeleton key
Appearance key
Base price 10 zm
Weight 3
Material iron
Monster use May be used offensively by monsters.
(
Name lock pick
Appearance lock pick
Base price 20 zm
Weight 4
Material iron
Monster use May be used offensively by monsters.
(
Name credit card
Appearance credit card
Base price 10 zm
Weight 1
Material plastic
Monster use Will not be used by monsters.

There are three unlocking tools in NetHack: the skeleton key, the lock pick (osaku to Samurai) and the credit card. The skeleton key and the lock pick are the only items allowing you to lock and unlock doors and chests. Credit cards can only unlock doors and chests, as a reference to their popularity in films for jimmying open door locks.

NetHack has two artifact unlocking tools: The Master Key of Thievery and The Platinum Yendorian Express Card.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Effects
    • 2.1 Usage
    • 2.2 Onlookers
    • 2.3 Monster use
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
      • 5.1.1 Breakage
      • 5.1.2 Strategy
    • 5.2 UnNetHack
  • 6 See also
  • 7 References

Generation

All unlocking tools are generated uncursed unless found on a bones level; since 3.6.1, they can also be found among the cursed items in the "bones" generated on some traps.

Effects

Usage

To unlock doors, apply the unlocking tool and then choose the direction of the door. To unlock chests, apply the unlocking tool while standing on the chest and then choose ">", for down or ".", for here.

The chance of successfully locking or unlocking a door depends on which tool you use, your dexterity, the type of lock, and whether or not you are a Rogue. The per-turn probabilities of success are listed in the table below. A cursed unlocking tool will also have a halved chance of success, applied after all other modifiers.

Tool For Rogues For non-Rogues
Door Box Door Box
skeleton key (70+Dex)% (75+Dex)% (70+Dex)% (75+Dex)%
lock pick (3*Dex + 30)% (4*Dex + 25)% (3*Dex)% (4*Dex)%
credit card (2*Dex + 20)% (Dex + 20)% (2*Dex)% (Dex)%
Any weapon (bladed or not) (not possible) 2*wldam (die size against large monsters) (not possible) 2*wldam

For Rogues, the lock pick has a higher (un)locking chance than the key for boxes at dexterity 17 or higher, and for doors at dexterity 21 or higher (usually achievable only with gauntlets of dexterity). For non-rogues, the key is better than the lock-pick except at normally unreachable dexterity levels, and in all cases the lock-pick has better chances than the credit card.

If you have not succeeded after 50 turns, you give up. This exercises your strength if using a non-bladed weapon, and exercises dexterity if using a tool or bladed weapon; the exercise is only counted once you've succeeded or given up. each failed attempt is worth nothing alone.

When unlocking chests and boxes with bladed weapons vs. other weapons, the chance of succeeding is the same, but the effects are different. Edged weapons have a small chance of breaking on every failed unlock attempt. Non-edged weapons have a 33% chance of damaging the chest, which destroys the lock completely; in that case, all potions within are broken, along with a 33% chance of breaking every other item.

The message given varies depending on the material involved, as detailed below, and occurs in the form "A(n) <item> <message>!" (e.g. "An orange potion shatters!")

Material Message
Paper torn to shreds
Wax crushed
Veggy pulped
Flesh mashed
Glass shatters
Wood splinters to fragments
Anything else destroyed

Onlookers

If a watchman sees you picking a lock, he may warn you or become hostile. If a warning is given, a trap is automatically added to the door in question.

Attempting to apply a credit card at a shopkeeper or the Oracle will produce the message "No checks, no credit, no problem." Attempting to apply an unlocking tool on a visible monster (other than a disguised mimic) in any other situation will produce the message "I don't think <monster> would appreciate that.".

Monster use

Some monsters with unlocking tools in their inventories may use them to unlock doors. [1]

Strategy

Credit cards are the lightest unlocking tool, but also the slowest, and cannot re-lock objects like the others. Lock picks are the heaviest and most expensive, and for a Rogue with 18 dexterity they give a 97% chance of (un)locking a box in one turn. However, in all other circumstances, skeleton keys are faster, as well as cheaper and lighter.

Being corroded or rusted does not impede the operation of any unlocking tool; however, cursed tools have only half the chance of unlocking that uncursed tools have.

While it is possible and sometimes reasonable to kick down doors, especially when without an unlocking tool, it has some adverse consequences.

  • Kicking wakes up nearby monsters. This includes the fabled invisible nymph. (This can have a major effect on your game, and is one of the main reasons you might choose to avoid kicking doors.)
  • You cannot close and/or lock doors to partition out spawned monsters if you have kicked them down (unless you have the wizard lock spell or a wand of locking).
  • For characters with low Strength and Constitution, kicking can take longer, unless wearing kicking boots. (Note that for characters with high values in those physical statistics, even an unlocked door can be faster to kick down than to open naturally if approached on the diagonal, because open doors, as opposed to destroyed doors, must be approached orthogonally.)
  • The door might be attached to a shop closed for inventory. (You can check this by examining the square orthogonally next to the door using the : command, except in a few corner cases related to bones levels.)
  • Kicking doors is impossible while riding or levitating.

History

All the unlocking tools first appear in NetHack 3.0.0. In addition, the NetHack 3.0 Series had special shaped keys that fit specific locks on chests and large boxes. For example, you might see "a chest (triangular keyhole)", for example, and a "triangular key" would open its lock much more quickly than a skeleton key, but a "square key" would not fit.

Doors did not have locks of any specific shape, and the shaped keys could not open them; you had to use one of the other unlocking tools.

Keys, and the locks that they fit, were as follows in NetHack 3.0.10:

Key Lock
round round
square square
triangular triangular
oval oval
octagonal octagonal
hexagonal hexagonal
cylindrical wide
irregular notched
conical large round
wedge-shaped large square

In time, the shaped keys were believed to add nothing of value to the game, and in NetHack 3.1.0 they were removed.

Variants

SLASH'EM

SLASH'EM changes unlocking tools, adding a chance of breaking[2][3], and also adding some artifact keys. Blessed unlocking tools and artifact unlocking tools will never break.

Breakage

Tool Breakage Chance
credit card 1/20
1/30 (tourist picking a door)
skeleton key 1/15
lockpick 1/30
1/40 (rogue)

Strategy

Since the unlocking tools now break, it is a good idea to carry more than one on your person. There's nothing worse than locking yourself into a shop, only to have your pick break when you try to get out again!

Once you get an artifact unlocking tool, this becomes less of a problem. Generally, you'll only need to worry about it being stolen. Note that the alignment keys are available to all players who progress far enough into the game. After this, use the key matching your alignment to avoid artifact blast, and keep the other keys in your bag of holding or in a stash.

UnNetHack

Starting with version 5.1, it is possible for UnNetHack monsters to pick up keys and use them to unlock doors.

See also

  • wand of opening
  • wand of locking
  • spellbook of knock
  • spellbook of wizard lock
  • The Master Key of Thievery, an artifact skeleton key
  • The Platinum Yendorian Express Card, an artifact credit card
  • Alignment key (SLASH'EM only)

References

  1. ↑ monmove.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 43
  2. ↑ lock.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 416 boxes, chests
  3. ↑ lock.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 518 doors

(e.g. "An orange potion shatters!") {|class="wikitable" |- !Material !Message |- |Paper |torn to shreds |- |Wax |crushed |- |Veggy |pulped |- |Flesh |mashed |- |Glass |shatters |- |Wood |splinters to fragments |- |Anything else |destroyed |} ===Onlookers=== If a [[watchman]] sees you picking a lock, he may warn you or become [[hostile]]. If a warning is given, a trap is automatically added to the door in question. Attempting to apply a credit card at a shopkeeper or the Oracle will produce the message "No checks, no credit, no problem." Attempting to apply an unlocking tool on a visible monster (other than a disguised mimic) in any other situation will produce the message "I don't think '''' would appreciate that.". ===Monster use=== Some monsters with unlocking tools in their inventories may use them to unlock doors. {{sourcecode|monmove.c|43|version=NetHack 3.6.0}} ==Strategy== Credit cards are the lightest unlocking tool, but also the slowest, and cannot re-lock objects like the others. Lock picks are the heaviest and most expensive, and for a Rogue with 18 dexterity they give a 97% chance of (un)locking a box in one turn. However, in all other circumstances, skeleton keys are faster, as well as cheaper and lighter. Being corroded or rusted does not impede the operation of any unlocking tool; however, [[BUC|cursed]] tools have only half the chance of unlocking that uncursed tools have. While it is possible and sometimes reasonable to kick down doors, especially when without an unlocking tool, it has some adverse consequences. * Kicking wakes up nearby monsters. This includes the fabled invisible [[nymph]]. (This can have a major effect on your game, and is one of the main reasons you might choose to avoid kicking doors.) * You cannot close and/or lock doors to partition out spawned monsters if you have kicked them down (unless you have the [[wizard lock]] spell or a [[wand of locking]]). * For characters with low [[Strength]] and [[Constitution]], kicking can take longer, unless wearing kicking boots. (Note that for characters with high values in those physical statistics, even an unlocked door can be faster to kick down than to open naturally if approached on the diagonal, because open doors, as opposed to destroyed doors, must be approached orthogonally.) * The door might be attached to a shop [[closed for inventory]]. (You can check this by examining the square orthogonally next to the door using the : command, except in a few corner cases related to [[bones]] levels.) * Kicking doors is impossible while [[riding]] or [[levitation|levitating]]. ==History== All the unlocking tools first appear in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. In addition, the NetHack 3.0 Series had special shaped keys that fit specific locks on chests and [[large box]]es. For example, you might see "a chest (triangular keyhole)", for example, and a "triangular key" would open its lock much more quickly than a skeleton key, but a "square key" would not fit. Doors did not have locks of any specific shape, and the shaped keys could not open them; you had to use one of the other unlocking tools. Keys, and the locks that they fit, were as follows in [[NetHack 3.0.10]]: {|class="wikitable" !Key !Lock |- |round |round |- |square |square |- |triangular |triangular |- |oval |oval |- |octagonal |octagonal |- |hexagonal |hexagonal |- |cylindrical |wide |- |irregular |notched |- |conical |large round |- |wedge-shaped |large square |} In time, the shaped keys were believed to add nothing of value to the game, and in [[NetHack 3.1.0]] they were removed. ==Variants== === SLASH'EM === [[SLASH'EM]] changes unlocking tools, adding a chance of breaking{{sourcecode|lock.c|416|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} boxes, chests{{sourcecode|lock.c|518|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} doors, and also adding some [[Alignment key|artifact keys]]. Blessed unlocking tools and artifact unlocking tools will never break. ==== Breakage ==== {|class="wikitable" ! Tool || Breakage Chance |- | rowspan=2 | credit card | 1/20 |- | 1/30 ([[tourist]] picking a ''door'') |- | skeleton key | 1/15 |- | rowspan=2 | lockpick | 1/30 |- | 1/40 ([[rogue]]) |} ==== Strategy ==== Since the unlocking tools now break, it is a good idea to carry more than one on your person. There's nothing worse than locking yourself into a [[shop]], only to have your pick break when you try to get out again! Once you get an artifact unlocking tool, this becomes less of a problem. Generally, you'll only need to worry about it [[nymph | being]] ''[[pixie | stolen]]''. Note that the alignment keys are available to all players who progress far enough into the game. After this, use the key matching your alignment to avoid [[artifact blast]], and keep the other keys in your [[bag of holding]] or in a [[stash]]. === UnNetHack === Starting with version 5.1, it is possible for [[UnNetHack]] monsters to pick up keys and use them to unlock doors. == See also == * [[wand of opening]] * [[wand of locking]] * [[spellbook of knock]] * [[spellbook of wizard lock]] * [[The Master Key of Thievery]], an artifact skeleton key * [[The Platinum Yendorian Express Card]], an artifact credit card * [[Alignment key]] (SLASH'EM only) == References == {{DOD}} [[Category:Tools]] {{nethack-360}}
